data.text: The CLICK-STAND Kickstand for Touring Bikes

What kickstands do you recommend for ur touring bikes when you are carrying a lot of gear. I have a Surly Disc Trucker bike. I just learned about this click stand?
CLICK-STAND Kickstand | The Best Kickstand for a Touring Bicycle?

We're checking out the Click-Stand kickstand in this vid, giving an overview of how it works and why we love it. Yep...that's right, we think it's the best k...

youtube.com

I had a pletscher on my long haul trucker that was amazing. They are frowned upon by many for potential chain stay damage but I never had an issue. I now roll with a midnight special and have no desire to put a kick stand on it though I may pick up one of those click stands someday
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: thank you! Someone else recommended the pletscher so I will check this out!
data.author: Lisa Fencik

data.text: .
data.author: Jaleondre Danoi

data.text: Looks like a waste of time compared to a kickstand. If your frame cannot handle the strain of a kickstand, you're not going to tour very far....
data.author: Heinrich Benz

data.text: it has more to do with a traditional kickstand being too low below the center of mass on a loaded bike which results in too much strain and bike tipping over a lot. I use a hiking pole. I broke 2 click-stands and lost a 3rd. And I completely disagree. I get far on a "heavy" bike. She's 55kg. I just climbed my steepest 25% grade in Albania 2 days ago. I average 80-120km on a normal day. On flats my record is 204km. I've gone almost 3 months without a rest day and did 2613km in one month in +40C through the deserts and mountains of Washington, Oregon, and California during the wild fires with +18,000m elevation gain. On my current tour, it's been 2 months, 3300km distance, and 31,000m elevation. More weight doesn't equal getting nowhere. That's judgmental weakness or the UL marketing brainwashing talking
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: I do feel compelled to add that the Click-Stand that broke while on tour was given to him by me at no charge. Adir did not ask for this, but I wanted to support his adventure. When it broke I replaced. Had I known that he broke the second Click-Stand I would have replaced it with a "Mondo" Click-Stand which, with a larger diameter, would have served him better, but he didn't let me know. I've added a picture of a Mondo in use.
data.author: Tom Nostrant

data.text: I was a shamed and embarrassed for breaking 2 (user error I'm sure because I haven't heard of others breaking them) within a week so I ordered the 3rd via a friend :). I still recommend click-stand to light weight tourers going for a few weeks or couple of months. I didn't know about the mondo. Is this a new product? I didn't want to feel I'm taking advantage of you with 2 freebies in such a short time span. Since then, the road thought me to accept help or gifts because it's not about me. The act of giving shouldn't be taken away by the receiver. In some cultures it's offensive.
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: all good. I used kickstands all the time, perhaps 6000km of touring. On cheap off the shelf bike. Got no issues with weight, no sure how that became part of the conversation.
data.author: Heinrich Benz

data.text: sorry, I assumed by your statement that if a frame can't handle the strain of a kickstand it is implied because of the total weight on the bike. All good :)
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: P.S. Even hiking poles aren't immune to me. I broke one on this tour already. The bike fell on top of it and bent it. Still works but I can't collapse one of the 3 sections so I found a way to attach it to the side of the bike like a javelin lol. I am a use and abuse destroyer no matter how careful I try to be
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: That's how I travelled
data.author: Heinrich Benz

data.text: kickstands that clamp onto the chainstay are the worst. Just look at all the pictures of damaged and tweaked chainstays due to carrying real weight on a tour. Your mileage is due to not carrying much weight.

data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: P.S - met a French bike tourer yesterday evening at a gas station. Rode at night till midnight stopping twice to share food or beers with hospitable locals. He liked my hiking pole but I told him about your product being stronger and lighter and easier to fold and store for his light load and type of touring - and showed him how my hiking pole is broken so not the best idea if you're a use and abuse or you lose things all the time type of personality - he isn't‚Ä¶. He has your website info :)
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: If we can figure out the logistics I'd like to send you a Mondo Click-Stand. I've always had these; I don't advertise them as so pew people need them.
data.author: Tom Nostrant

data.text: oh wow! Ill email you. That's very generous of you! I've met a lot of heavier tourers than me out there, especially families where dad and mom carry all the heavy things for their 2-3 young children and use large bulky sticks or one holds the bike while the other runs to the store‚Ä¶ maybe advertise it and a asterisk for the plus 50kg club of full time tourer? We're out there ;)

data.text: I use a click-stand. Has served me well. When loading and offloading your bikebags then you need to adjust the angle a bit which you cant really do with a traditionsl side kickstand. Keeps the bike stable and off the ground.

data.text: I use a Pletscher ESGE Double Leg Center Kickstand on my Salsa Marrakech. It does require significant space for clamping to the frame, but it has a great capacity to handle a large, balanced load.

Michael J Lewis

data.text: this is great! I took an interest on some of ur other posts about ur cross country trips. I also live in PA. I am looking at the adventure cycling middle country route. How did u choose the Southern route option?
data.author: Lisa Fencik

data.text: ‚Ä¶stick extends out about a foot, can easily be slid forward toward the handle bars so not to be a hazard when not in use, as bicycle is parked against a stationary object, when pedestrian traffic is heavy, like against a fence near an entry/exit‚Ä¶and as stated, it serves as a multi functional tool..
data.author: Michael J Lewis

data.text: ‚Ä¶when in motion, stick includes a ‚Äúsafety triangle‚Äù which flutters around much like a flag
data.author: Michael J Lewis

data.text: ‚Ä¶How I chose the Southern Route option ‚Ä¶was by looking at a map of North America, specifically USA, because of wanting to eliminate, or at least cut down on the possibility of COVID restrictions/requirements and mandatory medical imperatives that could arise for a US citizen traveling outside of USA‚Ä¶then looking at that same map and seeking a route over which I had not yet traveled by bicycle‚Ä¶Southern Route across the USA filled the bill‚Ä¶restrictions have ‚Äúeased up‚Äù for now, for US citizens traveling abroad, and I am once again considering the possibility of implementing an overseas plan that had been placed on the ‚Äúback burner‚Äù because of COVID
data.author: Michael J Lewis

data.text: currently I have the ursus jumbo and it is great, but I have the feeling that the bars to which it is attached suffer a lot when opening and closing it, on the other hand, every x time I have to tighten the nut because it loosens and weakens the set. Besides, I carry a cane that I bought in a Chinese store, it is super light, adjustable and does its job perfectly. An acquaintance has made one with the handle of a paint roller and a piece of stick to paint with said roller, and hey, wonderful...
data.author: Jaleondre Danoi

data.text: I bought a fisherman's extendible bank stick, one end spike, one end threaded. screwed in a plastic rest for the butt end of a fishing rod. Then extend to the required length, light and cheaper that a click stick. I use it for different bikes and no problem of frame damage from a kick stand. It will even hold up the tandem with luggage, get a strap or something to hold the front brake on.
